access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a generic HIPAA authorization form covering all release scenarios, with 'At my request' as one of several purpose options.

red_flags: Blanket waiver for sensitive information (HIV/AIDS, substance abuse, mental health) bundled into authorization with no opt-out for specific categories
bright_spots: EHI Export offered as a named delivery option — rare among ROI forms
Spanish-language authorization form available, revised on same date as English version
Swellbox online portal provides fully digital request alternative
Descriptive filename convention includes language, format, and revision date
Granular record type selection with 17+ checkboxes and individual date fields

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — medical records page is well-organized with clear links, and web search directly surfaced the PDF URL.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital with one gap — form is fillable with ~100 interactive fields but requires printing for wet signature; fax and Swellbox portal provide electronic submission options.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — clean numbered sections, 2-page length, granular record type selection, but page 2 legal text is moderately dense and the sensitive info waiver lacks granularity.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: Patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — generic authorization form serves all release scenarios; patients must figure out to list themselves as recipient, though 'At my request' and EHI Export options show accommodation.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities — no notarization or in-person requirements, reasonable fee structure available separately, right to revoke stated; fees not disclosed on primary form and blanket sensitive info waiver is a minor concern.

overall.summary: Emory Healthcare provides a well-organized, technically competent records request process with standout features like EHI Export and Spanish-language support, held back by a generic authorization form that does not differentiate patient self-access from third-party release.
